MIRACLE OF MIRACLES I took my sewing to the DMV with me thinking I’d be there all day
—
Was out in under 30 minutes and was honestly disappointed that I couldn’t get more sewing done
—
So I went and sewed in the park instead 
—
Full pic coming soon!
.
.
.

Ooh la la TINY QUILT 57 ⭐️ Some of my all-time favorite fabric came from a vintage sleeping bag I found in Chicago on a thrifting spree with my friend @amandanadigart this past summer. I unstitched every single thread that held it together and used a bit of the tobacco-colored casing that you see here. There’s also scraps of black cotton throw pillow and little piece of blue chambray from an old favorite shirt
—
Available in shop 🎁
.
.
.
.

TINY QUILT 48 ⚡️Sewed this sweet one on the patio of friend and fellow artist @amandanadigart on the first night I got to Chicago. We sat and sewed after dinner while her kids played ball out in the yard until it was too deep blue to see
—
Made from calico scraps from SmartArt in Nashville, batted with a paper-towel folded in quarters (it’s what we had on the patio table) and the center square is a swatch of Amanda’s grandmother’s eighth-grade graduation dress. Sewn 4 June 2022
—
Available in the shop 🙌
.
.
.
.
.

NEW WORK ⚡️ idk what I’ll call them yet but I like the idea: 
① choose a “hero garment” 
② chop it into a a number of bits
③ this becomes the number of quilts in your new series 
④ develop a color palette for your series
⑤ develop a grammar for your series (like how shapes relate)
⑥ sew like the wind 🌬️ 
—
QUESTION FOR FOLKS WHO WORK IN SERIES: let’s say I then wanted to sell these quilts (and I’m not sure I do but hypothetically) would you suggest selling individually or as a series?? 🙆‍♂️ splitting them up feels painful
.
.
.
.
.

#TINYQUILT HOT OFF THE PRESSIN BOARD⚡️
—
TQ61 was made while sitting with friends in a sewing circle on the NOOK. We were talking about genealogy, family stories, and whether buried secrets are better left unknown or brought out into the light. It was a fascinating conversation that I didn’t want to end but that I’m sure worked its way into this piece somehow
—
Made of red-striped cotton that I found with my friend @therealnancylenehan in LA, white floral feedsack scraps, and backed with a pair of old shorts I found on someone’s stoop in my neighborhood. 
—
Made December 2, 2022
—
Available in shop if you have a big toe that needs to stay warm this winter
.
.
.
.
.

Some days I spend more time LOOKING FOR THINGS than actually sewing

Which is why I (selfishly lol) invited organization-expert Kim Soper to join us THIS WEEK for a workshop on the NOOK where she shares her best tips ✨especially for organizing creative workspaces✨
—
So if you’re like me and you want your space in shape for #2023, I hope you’ll join us THIS WEEK

More details at top link in bio 🙇‍♂️

—

① I’m collecting a bunch of fabric the various shades of White skin tones for an upcoming series and this piece has the added bonus of being magnificently sheer
② What motif is that?

④ that weave tho 🤩
⑤ adorable burgundy Swiss dot shirt
⑥ I think I’ll use this in an upcoming project where I’m recreating a map of a family cemetery from memory. It’s in the woods so I need a lot of leaf litter and texture 
⑦ yellow lace dress
⑧ exquisite!
⑨ more fodder for the Whiteness series
—
Stay tuneddddd
.

“Can you not be a little less intimate?” is what someone asked of me after a recent talk I gave on my #sexquilt series
—
Asking me to be “less intimate” felt like asking me to go back in the closet, and that was a hard feeling to sit with
—
But this is where I’m so thankful I’ve found #quilting: it gives me a constructive outlet for transforming and burning off negative energies 
—
To learn more about this project (why this shirt, for example) watch the most recent #softbulk where I talk about it in depth. It’s too much for one IG caption 
—
Y’all sew something good this weekend. Burn clean! Don’t let the funk stick around any longer than it has to in order to make something beautiful ✨
.
.
.
.
.

#WIP shot: halfway through the first quilt of this #memoryquilt commission (3 queens and 1 king! 🙆‍♂️
—
Maybe you joined me for the recent #unboxing 🤷‍♂️
—
This design was inspired by a quilt by my good friend @amandanadigart where she squeezed these biomorphic shapes into boxes. I’ll post that quilt in my stories ✨ I reduced the color palette (bc I only had blues and whites lol) and smoothed out the curves to make them mirror the natural curves of the garments
—
Just 3.5 more quilts to go! ✨
.
.
.
.
.

A FEW THOUGHTS ON LAST NAMES —
① Slave owners in the US often denied the people they enslaved a last name. Doing so was an attempt to separate families into atomized replaceable workers 
② That’s why on this quilt I can only sew the first names of the Black folks that my Langston ancestor enslaved, and we only know this because he listed each of his slaves by name in his will (along with his other property, horses, and tools)
③ Not having last names makes genealogical research so much challenging for researchers looking for Black family members today
④ That formerly-enslaved folks often started using their enslavers’ surname after Emancipation is something I have a lot of questions about
⑤ My last name is Foster, and in a patriarchal system there’s an explicit tendency to identify more with our father’s line, but in truth, we are equally part our mother’s line, both genetically and culturally 
⑥ Which is why for this project I’m signing my name Zachary Langston Foster. I am a Langston even if that fact is not reflected in my birth certificate. I have inherited the Langston genes and privilege and carry them in my White body
⑦ Hence this family cemetery quilt in my ongoing #southernwhiteamnesia project
.
.
.
.
.

I grew up hearing stories about a beloved Black nanny who was “like family” 
—
Cross-racial relationships can most certainly be “like family”, but that didn’t sound like the reality in the household I was hearing about 
—
“Like family” really meant you as a White person felt comfortable with that particular Black person in your house
—
That not the same thing as family 
—
I will never know the complexities of that particular relationship I heard so much about as a kid, but I’m adding “like family” to the same list as “I don’t see color”, “I have Black friends”, and the old White Southern trope: “we were always good to our help”
—
In this quilted family cemetery, my White ancestors chose who got to get buried inside the wall and who got buried outside. They must have seen some of the Black people they enslaved “like family” to some degree and thus granted them entry into the family plot, while others of the enslaved faced one last indignity and were buried just outside the wall of the family cemetery
—
May we work towards becoming truly family, and not just a nicety draped in polite language
.
.
.
.
.

Experimenting with #boustrophedon on a Monday morning
—
I just learned about #boustrophedon this week from @elysiaallalong. It’s an ancient way of writing found in various civilizations in which a line of writing wends its way through a text, some lines reading left to right, other lines reading right to left
—
I’m appreciating how it allows the eye to comprehend part of the text immediately and then invites the viewer to slow down to read the rest
—
Special thanks to @tree.textiles for finessing the wording of this opening line 🙇‍♂️
.
.
.
.
.

I’ve been thinking a lot about the power of #texture with this project and the artifice that Robin Deangelo calls the “cocoon of racial comfort”
—
I’m trusting the inherent softness of the microfleece/velour/silk to draw the viewer in, make them want to stroke it and wrap up in it, get all settled in while I read them a story
—
The story on this piece recounts an allegory about how Whiteness was whispered into the world 
—
Like the Garden of Eden, there’s a snake that has deceived many of us White folks (not exempting myself here) offering promises of a leg-up in exchange for a put-down
—
As @hotazznickey recently reminded me 👉 Tell the truth and shame the devil
.
.
.
.
.

We’re about the FLIP THE NOOK UPSIDE-DOWN ‼️ 
—
This week we’re launching #NOOKPODS which are local groups of folks getting together around the US 🇺🇸 (and next week in the UK, Germany, Canada, and Australia 🇬🇧 🇩🇪 🇨🇦 🇦🇺)
—
I’m really excited about this because I believe that the highest goal of social media ought to be to connect to one another and deep and meaningful ways
—
PODS can do that 🙌 They can be anything folks want them to be: IRL sewing circles, trips to museums and thrift shops, cozier virtual sewing circles 🧵
—
We have created spaces in the NOOK for PODS in LA, NYC, Raleigh/Durham, Chicago, Phoenix, San Francisco, DC/Baltimore, Atlanta, Asheville, Fort Worth, Austin, Seattle, Portland, Minneapolis, Detroit/Ann Arbor, Buffalo/Toronto, and Philadelphia, with more cities to come as we grow
—
What would YOU do with new #quiltyfriends in your area?? 👀
.

.

I wouldn’t say this piece is *easy* to read (but that wasn’t the intention after all). I want the reader to slow down, be rocked to sleep a little, listen to the lullaby
—

—

SNAKE-HANDLER is the follow-up piece to Our Children
—
If Our Children tells the story of great snakes that whisper Whiteness into the ears of waiting White babies, then SNAKE-HANDLER is the call to action 
—
When you realize you’ve internalized the whispers, the next step is to handle the serpent: tell the truth and shame the devil
—
Two whispers I’m working to dispel in myself:
① whisper: “All this belongs to you” ⇨  truth: it does not and it is not mine to take
② whisper: “You have all this because you work hard” ⇨ truth: lots of people work hard and don’t have all this 
—
The thing about these #whispers is they don’t have to be lies. They can be true as day and still deceive
.
.
.
.
.

🐍 THE DETAILS >>> 
① the pink color here was chosen intentionally as a reference to White skin
② two kinds of thrifted fringe bc I was going for a strong #churchbanner vibe
③ in case you haven’t seen the whole thing yet
④ the snake’s body is made of layers of commercial lace curtain. The transparency is an intentional nod to how snakes are constantly shedding their skin and reinventing themselves 
⑤ snake eggs inspired by @tenillefati: what are we doing today that may be planting seeds for future injustices?
⑥ date when I finished this piece disguised as a Bible verse
—

—

I’m sewing 2,047 squares to the back of this old quilt I literally rescued from a trash can 🗑️ 
—
Eventually this whole #vintagequilt will be covered in a loose grid of squares the size of postage stamps
—
Another piece in my #southernwhiteamnesia series, I want to understand better *how much* we know about our own personal histories (and how much we don’t)
—
More details soon, but the short explanation for 2,047 is that it’s the number of *direct ancestors* any of us have in the last ten generations 
—
And that’s just *parents, grandparents, etc* not aunts, uncles, cousins 
—
Our history is vast 
.
.
.
.

Me tasting Kashmiri chili powder for the first time 🌶️ 
—
OLD FRIENDS ARE THE SPICE OF LIFE <3 I took a week off and spent time with my good friend Beth aka @gneissspice at her home in Maine, telling remember-when-we-were-teachers stories, talking spices and quilts, listening to loons croon on the lake, and just (get this) hanging out
—
I am so grateful for the chance to witness everything my friend has built in the last few years: a family of five and a full-on spice business that supports her family and nourishes her community
—
It's an honor to have such a friend in my life
.
.
.
.
.

What do you get when you cross a QUILT, a SNAKE, and a STAINED GLASS WINDOW?

Find out on the latest episode of CRAZY QUILT, a podcast game-show where I invite another maker to pick a random wild card, reveal it on air, and we dream up an impossible quilt together

In this episode, I’m joined by @uditau and we brainstorm a stained-glass quilt inspired a snake 🐍 

Why listen to two people ramble on about impossible quilts? ① Basically because it’s FUN NONSENSE but also in all seriousness ② listening to the questions other artists ask themselves when faced with a challenge can spark an idea for YOU in your own creative practice

WE ARE OUR OWN PATCHWORK 🧵we put our pieces together in a way that fits just right for us and no one else🧵 we improv our entire lives together, looking for pattern looking for shape in experiences and relationships🧵 and when we find that pattern and shape → may we love our hard-won singular lives, and may the nay-sayers sit and study their own quilts for a while
—
I wish I had your quilts with me here in Tennessee @samuellukeart one of many places to ban gender-affirming healthcare and public displays of queer culture
—
I would  want to ask everyone in the street: what do you see? what do you notice? how does that make you feel?
.
.
.
.
.

NOW ON SEAMSIDE 🎧 As an a Southern expat living in a northern state, it’s often nice to connect with somebody from home. We see things about our roots now that perhaps we didn’t when we were growing up immersed in the culture, and how we make sense of all that, for me and Clare at least, requires the help of textiles.
—
@clare_hu was born in Atlanta to parents who’d immigrated from China in the 1990s. Clare now lives in Brooklyn, and in this conversation we explore:
① the role movement and immigration can play in an artist’s work
② how we can build bridges to the past no matter where we find ourselves in the present
③ how we can take up space in this world and exercise our power
—
You can listen to our conversation at link in bio 🎧 
.
.
.
.
.

In our last #SEAMSIDE conversation on Episode 5, quilt historian Jess Bailey aka @publiclibraryquilts and I discussed the role of storytelling in art history and the power of visual images to convey narratives, experience of feeling seen and recognized through images, and we talked about why Jess would rather her quilts be considered sturdy rather than soft

SUNDAY MORNING READ 📖I’m in the middle of “A Communion of the Spirits” by Roland L Freeman and this lady lit up my morning 
—
Nora Lee Ezzell, quilter from Alabama, photographed here in 1992 right after she won the NEA’s National Heritage Fellowship
—
Freeman drove up in her driveway and caught her hammering away all by herself on a new bathroom extension
—
She joked “I’ll kill you if you take my picture dressed like this” and then went off to change into the quilty regalia that you see here 
—

I got to be right by my grandmas side as she passed 🧡 now she’s with the ancestors
—
It’s finally time for her to rest after 107 years of giving birth to seven children, serving as a WWII nurse on the front lines, volunteering for decades at the local cancer-ward, and being an all-around bright light 
—
I wouldn’t trade a single thing for this last week by my grandma’s side, tending, nursing, cleaning, story-telling, story-hearing, and keeping vigil with my mom, aunts, uncles, and brothers
—
Now it’s time to rest rest rest 
.
.
.
.
.

Did I ever share the completed #AFTERLIFE series with y’all? I don’t think I did 🙆‍♂️
—
This was a collection of work I made last summer during my residency at @tossafter 
—
Each shirt came to me with a square already cut out by @opportunitythreads which makes #memoryquilts for people
—
I loved the scraps so much that they instantly became the basis for this collection
—
I paired each piece with another discarded/salvaged textile from the warehouse 
—
I then arranged each garment so to speak to the life of the unknown wearer
—
Most of these were donated to @tossafter and sold at auction to raise $$$ for their nonprofit work (but I held on to one 🤫)
.

Memory does not sort itself into discrete units 〰️ Memories of me blend into memories of you blend into memories all of us
—
I tell my part of the human story and you tell yours and together we get closer and closer to the truth
—
In this #memoryquilt for my Grandma, I’m adding a ribbon I found last night in *her* mom’s Bible
—
My great-grandma Foe made the beautiful #mariewebster tulip quilt you’ve seen in other pics
—
But in looking through her Bible last night, I learned so much about her:
① She was deeply intellectual. The tiny notes in the margins of each page—some in English, some in Portuguese—show a tightly integrated and scholarly reading of this sacred text
② She was attentive to her partner. Every time my great-granddaddy Alva would preach on a particular verse, she would note the date and place in the margin
③ She was a voracious reader. On the last page of the last book of the Bible, I was surprised to see that between 1930 and 1944 she read the entire Bible SIX times
—
All these beautiful traits I saw embodied in her daughter/my grandma
—
Who knows why Grandma Foe saved this ribbon? Who knows why it was tied in a loop?
—
For now this loop of ribbon serves as a portal for all the mysteries that orbit our ancestors 

.
.
.
.
.

MORNING WORK 🌻 finish the #blanketstitch along the edges of this #memoryquilt
—
I started down this path bc I didn’t have any suitable fabrics here in NC to bind this quilt off
—
But the more I see if this #blanketstitch the more I like it
—
Random notes on #blanketstitch so I’ll remember in the future:
① the phrase “resolves without concealing” keeps coming to mind. I think as I work on this #southernwhiteamnesia project using this stitch could become more and more prominent bc my aim there is to tell stories about the past in a way that allows for acknowledgement (not resolve, we cannot resolve the past ever)
② as much as I use #rawedgeapplique this method of finishing a quilt feels very of a piece
③ I always thought it was a shame to cover the knots along the margin of a quilt with binding !
④ now those same knots not only remain visible, they are integrated into the #blanketstitch and pinned down
.
.
.
.
.

This is the last time we ever heard grandma laugh 💜
—
I leaned in close to her bedside and told her she was the strongest person I knew
—
She chuckled and said she’d been strong for a long time (I think 107 years counts plenty)
—
I experimented a lot with this text treatment to get it #justright
—
I appreciate how the lettering forms an overall pattern that mimics the commercially embroidered collar of my grandma’s bathrobe
—
And because of that, one has to lean in and spend a quiet moment with the text before it reveals itself
—
Much like sitting bedside
.

Two morning thoughts as I work on this #memoryquilt for my grandma 🌻
① Memory, like velvet, is a shape-shifter // This purple velvet is so hard to photograph. The very thing that makes it so compelling irl (its give-and-take with light) constantly leaves my poor phone confused on what exactly it should be focusing on. But somehow all that feels just the way it should be when working with memory: it’s a shifty thing isn’t it
② Even our quilts have lifetimes // You can see here the whispers of earlier ideas that linger in this quilt. You may remember I’d stitched out my grandma’s name in gold, but it was just too strong, so it took it out. I wasn’t super meticulous about getting the tightest knots of stitches out, so they still dot the landscape here in a way I really like
.
.
.
.
.

You probably heard stories like this
—
Maybe you e experienced it yourself
—
How when someone passes something preternatural happens that makes us feel like somehow their spirit is still present 
—
These encounters often involve animals (birds are a favorite) and electricity (lights flickering)
—
For me and my mom, that moment came the day after Grandma died and it too the form of a summer breeze that sounded a windchime on the corner of our house that we’d never heard before and haven’t heard again since 
—
Grandma? Maybe. I sure would like to think so 💜
.
.
.
.

Working on a new piece in the #southernwhiteamnesia collection that explores #inheritedwealth in my family
—
A couple years ago I began to notice a strong correlation in my #familyhistory between access to higher education and the exploitation of Black labor: the same ancestors that enslaved other people were the same ancestors who had access to higher education
—
No real surprise there, but to see that same privilege pass from generation to generation (and eventually land on me) was eye-opening
—
Thus a quilt and a #crazyquilt at that
—
More to come 
.
.
.
.

FINISHED: Uncle Jim’s #memoryquilt 🙌 Another bathrobe. A flag. A referee uniform. And so many stories 
—
I’ve got a whole episode of #SEAMSIDE coming out next week with all the stories this quilt holds 
—
For now I’ll just add that it was *such a pleasure* to work side by side with my aunt on this quilt
—
Spending those days with her in her home, sharing stories, talking and not talking: THATS the stuff quilts are made of. Not fabric
—
That’s my new hot take and I’m standing by it lol 
.
.
.
.

I *love* how this quilter captures family photos in this quilt!

I found this gem poking around the archives at @internationalquiltmuseum looking for ideas for our upcoming workshop and now I have ALL SORTS of thoughts and it’s not even 9 am 🙆‍♂️

This piece was made by Susan Sharpe in 1979 in my homestate (NC, woohoo!) She hand-painted the images and then quilted them down 

And maybe your family looks like this or maybe it doesn’t. Maybe you know some of your ancestors names or maybe you don’t. For our ANCESTRAL SEWING workshops coming up on the NOOK >>> it’s ALL GOOD

Addie Broyles aka @dontfearthedeathcard is guiding us through how to we can work with our own family history (known/unknown, biological/chosen) to open up our creative practice 

I wonder what stories that might open up for you ??

Learn more at the link in bio 🙇‍♂️ for now suffice to say it’s happening SOON (Oct 31 aka Halloween) and it only costs $9 for this workshop and a whole month of NOOK

I hope to see you there!
.
.
.

We found this long length of lace in my grandma’s things and for the longest time we had no idea why she’d kept it
—
Then we found this portrait of my mom on her wedding day and THERE WAS THE LACE 
—
I love that her daughter’s wedding-day lace was something so special to her that grandma kept it rolled up safe in her dresser drawers 
—
What family stories are your textiles guarding? Is it time to let them tell their stories? Join us for ANCESTRAL SEWING with Addie Broyles aka @dontfearthedeathcard 
—
Addie is guiding us through reflections and exercises on how to work with your family lineage in your textile practice 
—
You can work with known or unknown relatives, biological or chosen ancestors. All are welcome here 🙌
—
Workshop’s on Halloweeeeeeen when the veil is thin
—
Link in bio for this gathering 🙇‍♂️ hope to see you there
.
.
.
.

Hey what’re you doing this year? Want to make a quilt unlike anything you’ve made before (and yet amazingly Y O U ?) 

Our 2024 #quiltalong on the NOOK called #destroythisquilt is a series of 24 short guided prompts that get us working  equally with the elements of creation and destruction (aka transformation)

The first prompt just dropped last week and (spoiler!) it’s called the Museum Five-Fold: we fold our foundation fabric into a little bundle, we iron in those creases, we unfold and then make whatever creases we see permanent somehow

*Here’s a sneak peek at mine* and there’s SO MANY different ways you can do this. The NOOK is all abuzz with ideas right now 🐝 

Curious?? It’s the perfect time to join #destroythisquilt ! More info at link in bio 🙇‍♂️
